title: 'My airline refused to correct a misspelt surname – and is now demanding another £290'
text:
Mohammad Wahidi writes

A few weeks ago I made flight reservations for my family to travel from Birmingham to Istanbul during the October half-term holiday. My son is disabled and we had been given a Family Fund voucher as part payment for the flights, which had to be booked through its travel agent, Inspire.

After completing the reservation online I immediately noticed that the letter “i” was missing from my eight-year-old son’s surname, which was spelt Wahdi. Obviously I had made the mistake when inputting our names. I contacted Lufthansa’s customer services, which said that it could be corrected for a fee of €25 (£21.61) but the travel agency had to do it.

However, Inspire says Lufthansa has refused to allow the correction and the only way my son can be sure of flying is for me to buy him a new ticket for an extra £290, which we cannot afford. I am puzzled as to why this is such a big deal. Can you explain?
